designConcept: Tune Crafter is a web application that allows people to create new music beats and control the music flow with simple hand gestures.

descriptions.title: The Challenge
descriptions.description: The challenge assigned by the course Advance Programming of Interactive System was to use cutting-edge technologies to create innovative user interactions within an application in a 4 week timeframe.

descriptions.title: The Solution
descriptions.description: We successfully created a web application that runs on Chromium based browsers and on devices that are equipped with a webcam and a microphone that allows people to play with the music flow and create beats using simple hand gestures and voice commands. We also developed a smartwatch app that communicates the heartbeat and receives tactile feedback of the music tempo directly on the watch.

points: Drawing sketches of the applications and defining the features of the application.
Defining the architecture of the application after conducting a technology research benchmarked of different tech stack and libraries.
Coding key features of the application such as user interaction through gesture recognition and the music flow control and the UI of the application.
Creating reports of the app performance with Google Analytics that will drive changes based on the user behaviours.
Defining the topic: Thanks to brainstorming sessions, we decided to focus on creating music beats and controlling the music flow.

Cutting edge technologies: To define the architecture of the app we based our decision mainly on the performance, the adaptability with other libraries, the community and the documentation of the technology. We took the path of a computer vision and speech recognition app that can be used from Desktop and Smartphones and that also connects with Android smartwatches.
Unexplored and innovative application: Combine the hand gestures recognition with the music control and beats creation and receiving live tactile feedback on the watch.

descriptions.title: Application Design
descriptions.description: The initial design phase focused on creating a UI and interaction system for a music application using hand gestures and speech recognition. We explored two primary design approaches:

points: DJ Console Interface: We considered a familiar layout resembling a DJ console, which would leverage users' existing mental models of music creation tools.

Innovative Interaction Design: Our goal was to enable users to create beats through simple, intuitive gestures like a two-finger touch. After three low-fidelity prototype iterations, we finalised the UI design.

descriptions.title: Gesture Mapping and Implementation
descriptions.description: We utilised the Mediapipe API to analyse hand tracking capabilities and selected specific gestures for action mapping. The primary challenge was designing a system that could initiate actions from any user position. Our solution was implementing a finite state machine that dynamically interprets gesture sequences to trigger specific actions.

points: Standard Mode: 4 drumpad sounds
Christmas Mode: 4 seasonal-specific sounds
Piano Mode: 4 piano chords for foundational musical composition
Experience with OpenCV, Mediapipe and Webkit libraries for hand gesture and speech recognition.
Design the architecture of the communication of the Web app with the Smartwatch using network sockets under the same internet connection and exploiting smartwatch features.
Valuable learning about the usability of and the discoverability of the feature of the application were collected thanks to user feedbacks.
Web application designed, implemented and lunched in 4 weeks timeframe.
The “wow effect” of the application created a word of mouth effect that bring 60 new users per month that try the platform.
Development of personal skills: User Interactions design, Web and Smartwatch development, Application tracking and User testing.
Live demo at Université Paris-Saclay.
Live demo and interview at Good Soup Media channel

designConcept: Digital Nomads Space is mobile app that connects like-minded professionals and helps them find ideal workspaces.

descriptions.title: The Problem
descriptions.description: In 2019, approximately 5.5% of employed people aged 20–64 years in the EU usually worked from home. The impact of the COVID-19 crisis more than doubled the share in 2020 to 12.3%. In 2021 there was a further increase in the share of people working from home that reached 13.5%. The problem is that digital nomads struggle to find free public places to work from and meet each others.

descriptions.title: The Solution
descriptions.description: The solution is a mobile application that allows digital nomads to find the perfect workspace based on their preferences and to organise in person meetings with other digital nomads.

points: Preparation of semi structured user interviews and observations sheets.
Finding participant, conducting user interviews and coding of the data collected.
Designing the user interactions, application interface and paper prototyping.
Developing the Hi-Fi prototype as an Android application.
Analysis of quantitative and qualitative data collected from the user testing.
Preparation of a 24-question semi-structured interview with 9 participants recruited in a Starbucks café in Madrid.

After the interviews, we asked the participant to perform 2 tasks: how they find the workplace for the day; how they contact and meet with other digital nomads. We let the participant perform the task while the team observed and took notes on the methods used by the participants.
Three user profiles have been identified: Student, Freelancer, and Corporate Employee. For each profile, the motivations and frustrations were identified based on the user interviews.

Using the material collected from the observation, a task analysis with the different steps was created to draw the user flow for the two tasks: Finding a place to work/study and Connecting with people.
For each profile, the task was divided into 4 steps that defined the current scenario.
User journey maps of the future scenario when the app will be available were created for the 3 profiles by addressing the frustrations and motivations of the users.

descriptions.title: Low Fi prototype evaluation
descriptions.description: Two different paper prototypes were created: one using menus and form interaction and the other using the direct manipulation style. The goal was to evaluate how the two designs fit the mental models of the participants. The evaluation has been made using the “thinking aloud” method. Evaluated attributes: efficiency, effectiveness, and user satisfaction. For this test we had 15 participants testing both prototype alternating which prototype was tested before to avoid biases in the answers. For each task that the user was performing we measured the time spent to complete the task, the number of clicks necessary to complete the task and the number of errors that the user made along the way. To conclude the usability test we asked the participant to fill anonymously a SUS questionary to evaluate the user satisfaction between the 2 prototypes and finally analysed all the quantitive and observations collected to identify the best candidate for the hi-fi prototype.

descriptions.title: Hi Fi prototype evaluation
descriptions.description: The Hi-Fi prototype was made using Android as this decision was imposed by the teacher of the class. The evaluation was conducted with a set of 16 participants that were recruited in Starbucks cafe in Madrid and we asked the participant to perform two task. While the participant were performing the test we took notes of the user comments, measured the time spent to complete the task, the number of clicks made and the number of errors made. We also asked the participant to complete the System Usability Scale (SUS) questionary and the the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ).

points: Complete user-centered design process that led us to create a system based on user needs.
Evaluate a system using quantitative data to compare results and provide evidence over people's opinions.
Rapid prototyping and iteration to test as many ideas as possible and quickly validate solutions.
User research validated the initial problem statement and confirmed the need for the proposed design solution.
The qualitative and quantitative data collected directly informed our user-centered design approach, ensuring alignment with user needs and expectations.
Two low-fidelity prototypes were systematically evaluated, allowing for iterative refinement and early user feedback.
A high-fidelity prototype was developed and extensively evaluated, demonstrating the design's effectiveness and readiness for potential implementation.
